tn.text: This chapter continues Job's speech, which started in [[:en:bible:notes:job:12:01|12:1]]. Job is speaking to God.

tn.ref: Man, who is born of woman
tn.text: This refers to all people, both men and women; all are born into this world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
This is an exaggeration to emphasize that people live only a short time. AT: "lives only a very short time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Being "full of trouble" represents experiencing much trouble. AT: "has many troubles" or "suffers much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He sprouts from the ground like a flower and is cut down
tn.text: Like the life of a flower, a person's life is short and is easily killed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: he flees like a shadow and does not last
tn.text: A person's short life is compared to a shadow that disappears quickly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Do you look at any of these?
tn.text: Job implies that he does not want God to pay so much attention to him. AT: "You do not look at any of these" or "You do not pay so much attention to these. Please do not pay so much attention to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here looking at some one represents paying attention to him in order to judge him. AT: "pay attention to" or "look for faults in"

tn.ref: Do you bring me into judgment with you?
tn.text: Job uses this question to show his surprise that God judges him even though Job is so insignificant like the flowers. AT: "But you judge me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
General Information: Job continues speaking to God.

tn.ref: Who can bring something clean out of something unclean? No one
tn.text: Job uses this question to persuade God to apply what he knows about unclean things to Job. AT: "No one can bring something clean out of something unclean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be expressed in active form. AT: "You determine a man's days" or "You decide how long a man lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The number of his months is with you
tn.text: The number of man's months being with God represents God deciding the number of months that the man will live. "You decide how many months he will live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have appointed his limits that he cannot pass
tn.text: Passing a limit represents living past a time that God has set for a person to die. AT: "you have appointed the time that he will die, and he cannot live longer than that.(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a man who is hired to do a job and goes home afterwards

tn.ref: There can be hope for a tree
tn.text: The abstract noun "hope" can be expressed with the verb "hope." The hope is explained in verses 7-9. AT: "We can hope that a tree will live again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"it might start growing again"

tn.ref: so that its tender stalk does not disappear
tn.text: Disappearing represents dying. AT: "so that its young shoot will not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Even though" or "Even if"
the part of tree that remains sticking out of the ground after someone has cut down most of the tree

tn.ref: even if it only smells water
tn.text: This describes the dead stump as if it could smell water to represent water being near it. AT: "even if only a little water is near it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"it will start growing"

tn.ref: and send out branches like a plant
tn.text: The tree sending out branches represents branches growing on the tree. AT: "and branches will start growing on it like a plant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Job uses this question  to emphasize that when a person dies, he is not present. AT: "and no one knows where he is" or "and he is gone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: As water disappears from a lake ... and do not rise again
tn.text: The fact that death cannot be reversed is compared to water that dried up and cannot return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: As water disappears ... as a river loses
tn.text: These two phrases are describing the same thought and are repeated to emphasize the fact that death is final. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Lying down represents dying. AT: "so people die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Rising again represents living again. AT: "and do not live again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: they will not awake nor be roused out of their sleep
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and are used together to emphasize that death is final. Sleeping represents dying and awaking represents living again. AT: "people who die will not live again and be raised from death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Job continues speaking to God.

tn.ref: Oh, that you would hide me
tn.text: This is an exclamation showing what Job wants very much but does not really expect it to happen. AT: "I wish that you would hide me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
"keep me locked up" or "keep me hidden"

tn.ref: and then call me to mind
tn.text: Call someone to mind is an idiom meaning to think about him.  AT: "and then think about me" or "and then remember me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: If a man dies, will he live again?
tn.text: The implicit answer is "no." AT: "If a man dies, he will not live again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
What "so" refers to is understood from the previous phrase. AT: "If he would live again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: to wait all my weary time there
tn.text: The phrase "my weary time" represents a time during which Job would be weary. AT: "to wait all my time there even though I would be weary" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The abstract noun "release" can be expressed with the verb "release."  AT: "until I should be released" or "until you release me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
General Information: Job continues speaking to God.
"I would respond"

tn.ref: You would have a desire for
tn.text: The noun "desire" can be expressed with the verbs "desire" or "want." AT: "You would desire" or "You would want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: for the work of your hands
tn.text: Here God's hands represent him making things. Job refers to himself as the work of God's hands. AT: "for me, whom you have made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
These two verbs together express a single action. AT: "attentively care for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
Footsteps represent his life or what he does  AT: "my life" or "the things I do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you would not keep ... My transgression would be ... you would cover up
tn.text: These three lines express the same thought and are used together to emphasize his confidence that God would forgive him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: you would not keep track of my sin
tn.text: Keeping track of Job's sin represents thinking about his sin. AT: "you would not look at my sin" or "you would not think about my sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My transgression would be sealed up in a bag
tn.text: Sealing transgression in a bag represents hiding it and refusing to think about it. This can be stated in active form. AT: "You would refuse to think about my transgression like someone who hides something in a bag" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you would cover up my iniquity
tn.text: Covering up something iniquity so that it cannot be seen represents refusing to think about. AT: "you would hide my iniquity" or "you would ignore my iniquity" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
General Information: Job continues speaking to God.

tn.ref: mountains fall and come to nothing
tn.text: "Come to nothing" is an idiom meaning be completely destroyed. This phrase expands on the word "fall" and emphasizes complete destruction. AT: "mountains completely fall apart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: rocks are moved out of their place
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form. AT: "rocks tumble down from their place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Like this, you destroy the hopes of man
tn.text: If it is easier in your language, you can put this phrase at the beginning of verse 18 and adjust the text accordingly. AT: "You destroy the hopes of man, just like ... dust of the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: you destroy the hopes of man
tn.text: Destroying hopes represents causing the things people hope for not to happen. AT: "You prevent the hopes of man from happening" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The abstract noun "hopes" can be expressed with the verb "hope" AT: "the things that man hopes for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Job continues speaking to God.
The word "him" refers to any person. AT: "You always defeat man" or "You always defeat people"
Passing away represents dying. AT: "he dies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Possible meanings are 1) the pain just before dying makes his face contract or 2) when a person dies, God makes the person's face look different.
This represents causing him to die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Being brought low represents being shamed. AT: "if they are disgraced" or "if people shame them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
